Roberts: These challenges again highlight the need for certainty and predictability on domestic farm policy, provided by timely and farmer-friendly implementation of the Agriculture Improvement Act of 2018. And, that is what today‚Äôs hearing is about. #FarmBill
Roberts: The 2018 #FarmBill provides important risk management tools, such as crop insurance, to mitigate the risks and losses from these unpredictable weather-related events.

Roberts: This fall, as producers are trying to harvest their crops, challenges have continued. Just this past week, Winter Storm Aubrey and cold temperatures threatened crops and livestock from Kansas to North Dakota.

Roberts: This growing season has been far from easy. During planting season, growers experienced an historic, wet spring, which delayed plantings in parts of the country. Others have acres that were completely prevented from being planted and are still recovering from floods.

Roberts: Members of this Committee know firsthand that producers, lenders, and rural Americans are facing another difficult year of low commodity prices, high input costs, and uncertainty in the marketplace.
Roberts: Overall, we worked together‚Äîin a historic fashion‚Äîto get the #FarmBill through Congress, signed by the President, and to USDA to implement < 1 year ago.

Roberts: SNAP improvements from the #FarmBill result in better oversight of payment error rates, modernization of the verification process, and focusing employment and training on the skills needed in the workforce.

Roberts: The 2018 #FarmBill also included several measures to improve the integrity of our nutrition programs, such as Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program and the Emergency Food Assistance Program.

Roberts: The bipartisan hemp cultivation provisions have garnered interest from producers and processors. A new crop can provide long-term economic opportunity for farmers when regs are implemented in a farmer-friendly manner & pillars of their risk mgmt tools are in place.

Roberts: Producers are monitoring animal disease prevention & management. The #FarmBill made a commitment to bolster animal health infrastructure by directing mandatory funds for efforts against animal diseases outbreaks & tools to combat animal diseases should they impact US ag.

Roberts: Important voluntary conservation programs were reauthorized and strengthened in the 2018 #FarmBill. I understand that regulations to implement many of these programs, such as EQIP, CSP and CRP, are expected to be published in the near future.

Roberts: USDA continues to roll out changes to #FarmBill programs. As of this month, producers are able to visit their local Farm Service Agency office to sign up and choose between the Agriculture Risk Coverage and Price Loss Coverage Programs for crop years 2019 and 2020.
Roberts: This year, the Senate Ag Committee has held several #FarmBill hearings, including an initial overview eight months ago with Secretary Sonny Perdue.

Roberts: This hearing continues our bipartisan work together. Republicans and Democrats, Congress, and the Administration, are working together to ensure #FarmBill programs operate as we intended and changes are implemented timely and in the most farmer-friendly manner possible.

Roberts: Thank you, Steve, for the efforts at the Department to implement what we know is a significant and important task‚Äîomnibus legislation that affects farmers, ranchers, businesses and rural communities across this country. #FarmBill

Of course, the CDBG-DR program is bigger than just PR, although PR does seem to have been singled out.  Many states, including NC, are implementing action plans or awaiting additional notices from HUD to use disaster funding that was appropriated last yr & in June of this yr.

The other affected states had to wait 18 months, which was bad enough, but Puerto Rico is STILL waiting...

ICYMI: In PR‚ÄîNearly 3,000 people lost their lives, and tens of thousands of homes were damaged. I've been to PR and seen these challenges first hand.

But that's not even the full story, rather than comply with the clear statutory deadline (included in bipartisan legislation signed by the President) to issue the Fed Reg notice, @HUDgov is still withholding the notice for PUERTO RICO.
Low and middle-income families can‚Äôt wait 547 days to rebuild after a devastating storm.

Issuing the Federal Register notice has taken longer in recent years.

After Sandy in 2012, it took 35 days.  After the 2017 hurricanes, it took 145 days.  And more recently it took 547 days, and even then the notice came only after Congress included a deadline by law.

Without this notice, states (like NC) cannot submit action plans to @Hudgov, sign a grant agreement, and begin to use the $‚Äînecessary steps that take at least several months once the notice is issued.

Unfortunately, Congress has never formally approved the CDBG-DR program. 

This means each time Congress gives $, @HUDgov must issue a notice in the Federal Register that outlines how the funds can be used.

In 2017 alone, Congress set aside more than $35 billion across the federal government for people recovering from major hurricanes: Harvey, Irma, & Maria.

To put this into perspective, HUD‚Äôs entire budget in the last fiscal year was approximately $54 billion.
Since 1993, Congress has provided more than $86 billion in funding for the CDBG-DR program.  As the severity and frequency of storms have increased, so has the need for funding. *climate change*
The grants primarily benefit low- and moderate-income people in the most impacted and distressed areas.

.@HUDgov‚Äôs Community Development Block Grant-Disaster Recovery program (CDBG-DR) is a flexible & vital tool for states & municipalities to recover from major disasters. Grantees use this funding to reconstruct damaged housing & repair public facilities such as community centers.
